intro: Astragalus valparaisiensis, commonly known as the Valparaíso milkvetch, is a perennial legume native to South America, particularly Chile. It is characterized by its slender, erect stems and small, yellowish flowers arranged in clusters. The plant has compound leaves with numerous oval-shaped leaflets, and it produces small, hairy pods that contain several seeds. It thrives in dry, rocky habitats and is often found in coastal areas. Astragalus valparaisiensis is valued for its ecological role in stabilizing soils and supporting local insect populations.
